stories.text:
A post I was looking at got [flagged] apparently at some point while I was reading the article, and then was marked [dead] (he's dead Jim!) by the time I came back to comment on it.

Totally understand that the site needs moderation and all, but when I came to this page (the submission page) I didn't see any link to rules or guidelines. Though now that I look, they are linked on the homepage.

Still wondering what those tags mean and how they are applied. Is there any transparency in HN moderation?
stories.title: Ask HN: A post can be [flagged] and [dead] but how?
Ptex – texture mapping system for production-quality rendering
Building a Twitter sidebar clone with Material-UI and React
How Democratic Is the World’s Largest Democracy? Narendra Modi’s New India
Follow Along with the Creation of the Next Great Internet of Things Technology
Evernote’s CEO on the company’s long, tricky journey to fix itself

stories.text:
I have talked to several people who struggle to figure out which tax deadlines apply to them and their entities, particularly when they have multiple entities. It takes away from peace of mind and makes them worried they'll get fined.

Is there a good solution to this, other than talking to multiple accountants? I've been thinking about creating a solution that uses CPA-validated tax deadlines and software to help business-owners track deadlines, and customize it to use a users' specific entity types. I would consult with multiple CPAs to make sense of the conflicting info for different entities, then create a software program that sends reminders based on a user's specific type.

Do you think this would be useful? Does something like this exist?
stories.title: Ask HN: How do you manage LLC tax deadlines (especially if you own 1 org)
